content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The length of stay in a hospital after receiving a particular treatment is of interest to the patient, the hospital, and insurance providers. Of particular interest are unusually short or long lengths of stay. A random sample of <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> patients who received the treatment was selected, and the length of stay, in number of days, was recorded for each patient. The results are summarized in the following table and are shown in the dotplot. Length of stay (days) <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="21" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Number of patients <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="13" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>13</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="11" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Determine the five-number summary of the distribution of length of stay.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The length of stay in a hospital after receiving a particular treatment is of interest to the patient, the hospital, and insurance providers. Of particular interest are unusually short or long lengths of stay. A random sample of <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> patients who received the treatment was selected, and the length of stay, in number of days, was recorded for each patient. The results are summarized in the following table and are shown in the dotplot. Length of stay (days) <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="21" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Number of patients <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="13" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>13</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="11" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Determine the five-number summary of the distribution of length of stay.

(b) Consider two rules for identifying outliers, method A and method B. Let method A represent the <math alttext="1.5 times I Q R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mo>Ã—</mo><mtext>IQR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> rule, and let method B represent the <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> standard deviations rule.(i) Using method A, determine any data points that are potential outliers in the distribution of length of stay. Justify your answer.(ii) The mean length of stay for the sample is <math alttext="7.42" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.42</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days with a standard deviation of <math alttext="2.37" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.37</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days. Using method B, determine any data points that are potential outliers in the distribution of length of stay. Justify your answer.
(c) Explain why method A might identify more data points as potential outliers than method B for a distribution that is strongly skewed to the right.

topic.text: 1.7: Summary Statistics for a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Calculate summary statistics, relative positions of points within a distribution, correlation, and predicted response.
